subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... And this is exactly my reason for mapping each letter to a specific sound represented by IPA. I had a hard time as well because I merge #33 & #34. #32 is
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Hello Paige,
>
> I pronounce "ah" and "awe" exactly the same. It's exactly the same
> sound I use for the first vowel in "nautical". For me, any distinction
> between QS letters #32, #33 and #34 is difficult to even imagine. This
> has been a stumbling block for me in trying to learn QS. I don't have
> a good way to guess which of these letters would be most appropriate
> to use for sounds that I cannot distinguish.
>
> (I have spent most of my life in the Western US, in the states of
> Oregon, California, and Washington.)
>

And this is exactly my reason for mapping each letter to a specific
sound represented by IPA.

I had a hard time as well because I merge #33 & #34. #32 is separate for
me. It took me a few weeks before I finally realized that I don't
distinguish between #33 and #34. I pronounce the vowel in "pot" in the
same way I pronounce the vowel in "Awl."

If you were like me, you were looking at the words and thinking "what
the hey! But there is no difference, so I must be missing something."

Luckily I had a little linguistics background, so as I paid attention to
how my mouth was not open for #34, I had a revellation. "Ah, that is my
Boston accent! That is why people made fun of me when I pronounced
Boston Bawston." I opened my mouth a bit more and pronounced Boston, and
had my girlfriend listen to both. She recognized that the open sound was
the way she expected to hear it. So then I knew.

Right now I am making a list of the 2000 most commonly used words in the
English language. I am transcribing them for standard American English.
Each time I come upon a #34 sound, I think, "No, that has to be
pronounced with #33." Then I look up the IPA and see that I was
wrong--so I cannot hear #34 at all.

If I understand QS at all, you don't need to figure out which letter to
use. You just need to figure out what sound you make, and use it for all
the words. That is your dialect, which will come through in your
writing--one of the nice parts of QS, users say. The trick is figuring
out which of the sounds you use.

But I really think a more precise way of describing the letters would
avoid a lot of confusion and give precision to the exact issue you are
talking about.

Paul
